awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Mechanisms of Bacterial Biofilm Aging and Anti-aging
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Mechanisms of Bacterial Biofilm Aging and Anti-aging

This project aims to elucidate the aging and disassembly process of bacterial multicellular communities known as biofilms. In natural environments, bacteria, once considered solitary, live socially in multicellular communities. These communities play critical roles in many aspects of ecology, agriculture, and sustainability. Understanding development of these bacterial communities is a topic of wide interest, yet the existing knowledge on this subject, particularly in the aging and disassembly phase of the developmental cycle, is largely lacking. The project focuses on how important environmental and physiological signals influence bacterial social development. Learning about this signaling process will increase basic understanding of bacterial multicellular development and enhance the ability to modify these bacterial communities in practical situations such as agriculture and sustainability. The project will also integrate aspects of research and teaching and will extensively involve training of graduate students and recruitment of undergraduate students motivated to gain hands on research experiences early in their education. The project will also serve as a platform to improve curricular offerings, will involve community outreach, and will support specific STEM programs in the region.

The goal of this project is to elucidate the aging and disassembly process of multicellular development in a model bacterium Bacillus subtilis. A combination of cell biological, molecular genetic, and biochemical approaches will be taken to specifically study how reactive oxygen species (ROS), a common and important environmental signal, triggers oxidative stress and influences bacterial multicellular development and cell differentiation in B. subtilis. The PI will test the hypothesis that biofilm aging and disassembly is a function of ROS-triggered DNA damage and its effects on the proteolytic breakdown of various cellular regulatory components. This could inform our understanding of bacterial multicellular structures and how the dynamics of their regulation compares with some aspects of eukaryotic multicellular organization, while further revealing a molecular link between ROS-triggered DNA damage response and bacterial multicellular development. It will extend the current understanding of the biological function of the DNA damage response beyond free-living bacterial cells and allow for a better understanding of how bacterial multicellular communities age and disassemble in response to both internal and environmental signals.

por.por_cntn:
Biofilms are bacterial multicellular communities that are predominant in nature and play critical roles in ecology, health, agriculture, etc.  It is known that throughout the life cycle of a biofilm, the community ages, transitioning from biofilm assembly to disassembly in response to internal and external signals. However, knowledge of the signals and regulation that control the biofilm life cycle, largely lacks. This project, “MCB1651732, CAREER: Mechanisms of Bacterial Biofilm Aging and Anti-aging” aims to characterize the regulation of biofilm development, aging, and dispersal by oxidative stress in a model bacterium Bacillus subtilis, and to better understand biofilm formation as a bacterial multicellular developmental life cycle. 

Summary. Upon the completion of this project, the PI’s lab has, 1) elucidated the aging and disassembly process of biofilm and how oxidative stress influences biofilm development in the model bacterium B. subtilis; 2) established the molecular link between reactive oxygen species (ROS), a type of cell damaing chemicals, -triggered DNA damage and bacterial biofilm development; 3) and gained a better understanding on how biofilms age and disassemble in response to both internal and environmental stress signals. During the supporting period, the PI’s lab published 10 peer-reviewed research articles and 3 review papers on the supported research, and filed one provisional patent. The PI has advised a total of 9 graduate students. Among them, 6 already successfully graduated. The PI’s lab also hosted 4 visiting scholars and supported a total of about 70 undergraduate researchers through different programs (REU, co-op, directed-study, capstone, volunteer, etc).

Intellectual Merit. The PI’s lab demonstrated the important role of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in biofilm aging (Gozzi et al., npj Biofilms and Microbiomes, 2017), the role of a secondary metabolite, pulcherriminic acid, as a novel antioxidant during biofilm development (Angelini et al., npj Biofilms and Microbiomes, 2023), and the importance of iron in energy metabolism during biofilm development (Qin et al., Nature Communications, 2019). A novel serine-sensing mechanism regulating Bacillus subtilis biofilm development was also explored (Greenwich et al., J. Bacteriology. 2019). The lab also studied B. subtilis-roots interactions and revealed how sucrose, a photosynthetic sugar secreted by plant, triggers a novel signaling cascade essential for B. subtilis rhizosphere dominance (Tian et al., ISME J, 2021). The project also allowed the PI’s lab to further investigation of biofilms to bacteria isolated from extreme environment, the Atacama Desert, and characterize mechanisms of environmental resilience in those bacteria (Reverdy, et al. Frontiers In Microbiology, 2024; Cavanaugh et al., bioRxiv 2024a; Cavanaugh et al., bioRxiv 2024b). A provisional patent on engineering B. subtilis to produce large quantity of pulcherriminic acid for industrial applications was co-filed with Dr. Shemesh’ group in Israel (Application No. 63/598,190).

Broader Impacts. The PI provided mentorship for 9 graduate students, 4 visiting scholars, and about 70 Northeastern undergraduate researchers. The lab also hosted 5 NSF REU students and 3 of them presented research in REU National Symposium. The lab hosted annual lab visit by high school students from Acton-Boxborough Regional High School (Acton, MA) and mentored the student research projects as educational outreach. Here is a summary of achievement by graduate and undergraduate students in the PI’s lab working on the supported project. i) Graduate student achievements: Jennifer Greenwich: University Graduate Student Teaching Excellence Award (2018), Alicyn Reverdy: College of Science Graduate Student Leadership Award (2019) and awardee of NU Huntington 100 (2020), Leticia Angelini: College of Science Graduate Student Diversity Award (2020), Nicole Cavanaugh: NSF Graduate Fellowship (2022) and College of Science Graduate Student Excellence Award (2024). Three graduate students received the Provost Dissertation Completion Award: Greenwich (2018), Habib (2019), Reverdy (2020). ii) Undergraduate achievements: Kevin Gozzi: NSF Graduate Fellowship (2018), Kevin is now a Harvard Rowland Fellow, Phillip Wasson: ASM Summer Research Fellowship (2019), Brian Best: Fulbright Scholarship and “ThinkSwiss” Scholar (2020), Gillian McClennen: Goldwater Scholarship (2023). Undergraduates in the lab also won numerous university research awards (~ 35 NU undergraduate research PEAK awards).
